results.title: The Irishman
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, Anthony Buckley and Forest Home Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel of the same name by Elizabeth O’Connor. Set in Northern Queensland in the 1920’s, it is the story of a proud Irish Australian teamster and his family as they face the competition from motorised transport. This is the story of a family experiencing events which they cannot control in the face of progress and change. Stars Michael Craig, Simon Burke, Robin Nevin and Bryan Brown.

results.title: New voices
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
In a world where the fortunes of one people crisscross with others, it is to be expected that the voices of Muslim countries will be raised on world issues. At the United Nations and other international gatherings, this film watches and listens to the new leaders of the Islamic world. What you see and hear has much meaning for you, and even more significance for the new African nations among whom Islam is a live and growing force.

results.title: Aspirations
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Education, political reform, and technology are all being used to serve the aims of the society of North Africa and the Middle East. The primary aim is liberation from colonial control and from the grip of poverty. Throughout the region this film finds much new development, aimed for the most part at the production of larger, more varied crops and the organization of new industry. Within sight of the waterwheels of antiquity can be seen the rise of vast power dams and pumping stations, and beyond mud villages steel and concrete cities, schools and factories can be seed.

results.title: The Irish in Australia: Echo of a Distant Drum
results.creator_credit: Matthew Flanagan, Michael Balson, Richard Dennison and Orana Films
results.brief_description: One in three Australians have Irish origins - and this is reflected in the national character. The humour; the sense of self-mockery; ideals of fair play; the dislike of pomp and bombast; the celebration of noble failure; are all characteristics both Irish and Australian. The story of the Irish in Australia has been one of conflict, often echoing dramatic events in Ireland. It’s a history that has been potentially so divisive that it has been ignored. But it is the key to understanding why Australia has become the democratic nation that it is, and yet remains ambivalent on national issues.

results.title: The Incredible human machine
results.creator_credit: Irwin Rosten and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: A journey through the wondrous inner world of the human body. Explore the fascinating, microscopic universe that exists within us all. How does the eye adjust in light? How do our muscles enable us to move? How does the eardrum process sound? With the help of sophisticated photographic techniques you are now able to discover the wonders of the internal human world.

results.title: The Impact of the west
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
The counter-wave of western expansion breaches the closed frontier of Islam - Napoleon in 1798, quickly followed by the British. From the Muslim defeat rose the new nationalism, an upsurge intensified by two world wars and the emergence of the new state of Israel. Part two of the revised seven-part series.

results.title: Algeria
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Indicative of the direction and strength of Muslim revolt against European colonisers was the struggle for Algerian independence. This film recapitulates Algeria’s history up to the signing of the French-Algerian agreement and the last-ditch stand of the secret, outlaw European army. Figures of the Algerian resistance emerge on the screen as the film follows the Algerian resistance army to their mountain stronghold and takes a look at the peace conferences in France. Narrated by James Beveridge. Edited by Dennis Sawyer.

results.title: The Irish empire
results.creator_credit: Alan Gilsenan, David Roberts, Dearbhla Walsh, Ritchie Cogan, Cafe Productions (London), Hilton Cordell Productions and Little Bird (Dublin)
results.brief_description: Ireland is just a tiny country that has never sought domination, yet it has established Irishness and Irish power bases and communities from Chicago to Vladivistok, from Australia to Argentina. There is no physical empire, but an empire of imagination, a virtual empire, whose followers outnumber the native population in Ireland by over fifteen to one. From a home population of just 4 million, some 70 million people around the world call themselves Irish, or claim Irish descent. This is a thought-provoking exploration of how the Irish have so often triumphed over adversity and established themselves all over the world. It explores the past and present attitudes and ideas which have allowed the Irish people to spread across the world without loosing a sense of identity generations later. Narrated by Fiona Shaw.

results.title: The Impressionable years: American children and the public library
results.creator_credit: Peter Elgar and United States Information Service
results.brief_description: Describes a young girl’s first experience of the children’s room of the New York Public Library. Evokes in an imaginative way the pleasures, satisfactions and companionship children can find in reading. Shows story hours, simple reference work and borrowing routines. Emphasises the child’s freedom of choice and the way in which the library is scaled to their requirements. Narrated by Henry Fonda.

results.title: The Rough road to freedom
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Describes the western influence in North Africa and the Middle East. Technology which had halted for a thousand years, spurts ahead as new revolutionary leaders, like Bourguiba, Nasser and Kassem, reogranise feudal society and restore the pride of the people and the fertility of their soil. In the drylands of the United Arab Republic you climb great engineering works which irrigate the fields, power the machinery and give light to schools and colleges where a new generation of Egyptians prepare for modern life.
